description: From Latin sequēla (“that which follows”), from sequi (“follow”). Compare sequel and sequence.

entries.meaning: (pathology) A disease or condition which follows chronologically after an earlier disease or problem, being either wholly or partly caused by it, or made possible by it.
examples: ‘Ay, ay,’ said Stephen testily, ‘it is showy enough to look at, no doubt, but these are only the superficial sequelae. There is no essential lesion.’

entries.meaning: That which follows; an inference or corollary.
